title: 109_hr744
content: The Act titled "Internet Spyware (I-SPY) Prevention Act of 2005" addresses penalties for unauthorized activities related to computers. The "Internet Spyware (I-SPY) Prevention Act of 2005" introduces a new section, Sec. 1030A, which penalizes the illicit indirect use of protected computers. It specifies fines or imprisonment up to 5 years for intentionally accessing a protected computer without authorization and using a computer program for another federal criminal offense. The "Internet Spyware (I-SPY) Prevention Act of 2005" introduces section 1030A, penalizing unauthorized access to protected computers with fines or imprisonment up to 2 years. Civil actions under state law cannot be based on violations of this section. The terms "protected computer" and "exceeds authorized access" are defined in section 1030, and "personal information" is also defined. The term 'personal information' in section 1030 includes a first and last name, address, email, phone number, SSN, driver's license, passport number, credit card or bank account details, and associated passwords. This section does not restrict authorized investigative or intelligence activities by law enforcement agencies. The legislation defines 'personal information' and allows for authorized investigative activities by law enforcement agencies. It also includes a new item in the table of sections related to intelligence agencies. SEC. 3. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2006 through 2009, $10,000,000 allocated to the Attorney General for prosecuting spyware, phishing, and pharming. SEC. 4. Findings and sense of Congress on the enforcement of cybercrimes. Congress finds that software and electronic communications are increasingly used by criminals to invade computers without authorization, particularly through spyware and phishing scams. These schemes aim to obtain personal information for theft, causing devastating damage and undermining confidence in using the Internet. Continued development of innovative technologies is crucial in combating spyware. Response to consumer demand is crucial in the fight against spyware. Congress emphasizes the importance of prosecuting those who use spyware for criminal activities, phishing, and pharming scams. The House of Representatives passed the bill on May 23, 2005.
